document.masterDocTitle: New Synonymies in Neotropical Platypodinae (Coleoptera: Curculionidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Synonymies in Neotropical Platypodinae (Coleoptera: Curculionidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
I compared the male Chapuis types of
P. pulicaris
and
P. segnis
in IRSNB and concluded they were conspecific in light of current knowledge of the variability of
E. segnis
. Independently, T. H. Atkinson (Austin, Texas) made the same comparison and came to the same conclusion. I also can confirm the earlier synonymies of Reichardt (1964) of
P. melanurus
(Chapuis male holotype in IRSNB) and
P. schaumi
(Chapuis male and female types in ZMHB). Similarly, I have verified Schedl â€™ s synonymization of
P. poriferus
(Chapuis male syntypes in NHMUK) with
E. segnis
.

The holotype of
P. hians
in NHMUK is a female. Schedl (1972) established the appearance of the male when he synonymized
P. hians
with
P. apertus
and
P. perpusillus
, two other Chapuis species described in the same monograph ( Chapuis 1865 ); the syntypes of the latter two species include both sexes. I have examined type material of all three species as well as many South American specimens of both sexes identifed by Schedl or myself as
Euplatypus hians
, and I can find no differences between these specimens and Central American specimens identified as
E. segnis
.

The only known specimen of
E. costaricensis
(in NHMW ) is the male holotype from Costa Rica . The only known specimen of
E. nitidipennis
(in NHMW ) is the male holotype from French Guiana . I compared the holotype of
E. costaricensis
directly with the Chapuis types of
P. apertus
and
P. perpusillus
as well as with other males identified by Schedl as
E. hians
,
P. apertus
, or
P. perpusillus
in NHMW . I later compared the holotype of
E. nitidipennis
with the holotype of
P. apertus
and subsequently with all my other specimens in this complex. For now, these all should be considered one common, widespread species. The unique male of
E. nitidipennis
is distinguishable, but probably an aberrant individual, as I have seen no others like it among hundreds of male specimens of
E. segnis sensu novo
.

Now that many specimens are available from throughout the Americas, it is apparent that there are no consistent distinctions justifying retaining more than one name for them. Until genetic data are available, the null hypothesis should be that
E. segnis
,
E. hians
,
E. pulicaris
,
E. bellus
,
E. costaricensis
, and
E. nitidipennis
represent just one widespread species which is quite variable in size (3.0 â€“ 4.3 mm from frons to posterior margin of elytra).

The International Code of Zoological Nomenclature does not require one to follow page precedence when choosing among names published simultaneously in the same work ( International Code of Zoological Nomenclature 1999 : Article 24.2.2). Of the names published in the Chapuis (1865) monograph,
P. pulicaris
is first, but has rarely been used; the names
E. bellus
,
E. costaricensis
, and
E. nitidipennis
, too, have rarely been applied. As first revisor, I choose the name
Euplatypus segnis
over
E. hians
for this taxon, as the former has been used more actively in recent ecological and biogeographical research ( e.g ., Equihua M. and Atkinson 1987; Ã˜degaard 2004 ;
Alvidrez-Villarreal et al . 2012
). When we combine records for these species, we see that
E. segnis
is one of the most widespread and abundant 1Neotropical platypodines, having been repeatedly collected from nearly every country between Mexico and Argentina as well as from the West Indies ( Atkinson 2016 ; Kirkendall 2017 ).
